title: Fracking: government has 'failed to implement' key safety recommendation
text:
Print 
Shale gas industry-funded task force says ministers have failed to implement a key recommendation of the Royal Society report they commissioned 
Ministers have failed to implement a crucial recommendation of the flagship Royal Society report into fracking safety, designed to ensure wells don’t leak dangerous chemicals, Lord Smith, the former Environment Agency chairman has said. 
Lord Smith, who now chairs the Task Force on Shale Gas - a group that is being funded by the shale industry to conduct independent research on fracking - said it had concluded regulation was “adequate but it could be made better”. 
In a report on Wednesday, the Task Force says there should be compulsory independent monitoring of wells after fracking takes place to check for potential leaks rather than the companies doing the checks themselves. 
The measure was first recommended by the Royal Society and the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2012 , after they were commissioned by the Government to assess the risks of fracking. 
Lord Smith said ministers had implemented most of the Royal Society’s recommendations but independent monitoring was the “glaring exception”. 
He said: “We believe it should be independently monitored and inspected. The status quo has no requirement of independent monitoring, it is effectively left up to the companies themselves to report. For public confidence, it is important that it is independent.” 
He said leaks could be dangerous “if the well integrity is breached and it gets into groundwater in substantial quantities… and people then drink it”. 
“You need to make sure you have belt and braces in place to make sure that can’t happen. That means monitoring the well integrity; making sure it has been properly constructed and it is constantly monitored to make the sure moment a breach is identified you stop. “ 
A spokesman for the Department of Energy and Climate Change said it already required independent inspections before fracking takes place. 
He added: “The Health and Safety Executive has existing powers to carry out independent inspections whenever it has a reason to do so. It is in a company’s interest to have the best possible health and safety regime for their own operations.”
